content.body:
* jarhar: The _‚ÄúA CSS Animation running on an element within a \<details> element is canceled after the \<details> element is closed‚Äù_ test at https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-animations/animation-canceled-by-parent-details-element-being-closed.html times out in Chrome, while passing in Firefox and current Safari.

But the patch in https://github.com/WebKit/WebKit/pull/18785 for implementing auto-expanding `<details>` makes it now time out in Safari too.

The reason it times out (both in Blink and patched WebKit) is that the `cancel` event never fires.

I‚Äôm going to make time to investigate it more, but it‚Äôs not immediately clear to me why the changes made for auto-expanding `<details>` would cause that test to fail.

*

But the patch in https://github.com/WebKit/WebKit/pull/18785 for implementing auto-expanding <details> makes it now time out in Safari too.

The reason it times out (both in Blink and patched WebKit) is that the cancel event never fires.

I‚Äôm going to make time to investigate it more, but it‚Äôs not immediately clear to me why the changes made for auto-expanding <details> would cause that test to fail.

content.body:
Hi! Can I request some historical information here? üòÖ
I was wondering what kind of arguments were raised for the current CSS custom property syntax, more specifically; was the SASS-like dollar syntax considered, and why didn't custom properties adopt something similar to that?
Tried searching the whatwg github issues, but couldn't find any discussion related to this. Apparently some discussions are held in IRC/Matrix, so there would not be public logs if that's the case?

> <@axo10tl:matrix.org> Hi! Can I request some historical information here? üòÖ
> I was wondering what kind of arguments were raised for the current CSS custom property syntax, more specifically; was the SASS-like dollar syntax considered, and why didn't custom properties adopt something similar to that?

 CSS is specified in W3C, not in WHATWG
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @axo10tl:matrix.org
Hi! Can I request some historical information here? üòÖ
I was wondering what kind of arguments were raised for the current CSS custom property syntax, more specifically; was the SASS-like dollar syntax considered, and why didn't custom properties adopt something similar to that?
CSS is specified in W3C, not in WHATWG

content.body:
jarhar: The _‚ÄúA CSS Animation running on an element within a \<details> element is canceled after the \<details> element is closed‚Äù_ test at https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-animations/animation-canceled-by-parent-details-element-being-closed.html times out in Chrome, and in Safari built from https://github.com/WebKit/WebKit/pull/18785 ‚Äî apparently because, with the switch to using `content-visibility: hidden` to close the `details` element (rather than removing the element from the DOM), the `cancel` event never fires.

Per-spec _is_ the `cancel` event actually supposed to fire at an element when `content-visibility: hidden` is set on an ancestor?

If it‚Äôs not supposed to fire, then I guess that test needs to be changed.

But if it _is_ actually supposed to fire, then I guess that‚Äôd mean both Blink and WebKit have a bug in their content-visibility implementations that needs to be fixed?
content.formatted_body:
jarhar: The ‚ÄúA CSS Animation running on an element within a <details> element is canceled after the <details> element is closed‚Äù test at https://wpt.fyi/results/css/css-animations/animation-canceled-by-parent-details-element-being-closed.html times out in Chrome, and in Safari built from https://github.com/WebKit/WebKit/pull/18785 ‚Äî apparently because, with the switch to using content-visibility: hidden to close the details element (rather than removing the element from the DOM), the cancel event never fires.

Per-spec is the cancel event actually supposed to fire at an element when content-visibility: hidden is set on an ancestor?

If it‚Äôs not supposed to fire, then I guess that test needs to be changed.

But if it is actually supposed to fire, then I guess that‚Äôd mean both Blink and WebKit have a bug in their content-visibility implementations that needs to be fixed?

content.body: shower thought: Wouldn't it be nice to have a "sameoriginmessage" (name to be bikeshedded) counterpart of the "message" Event type which code could consider implicitly trusted (or not)?
freddy: possibly, or some kind of event listener filter option
content.formatted_body: freddy: possibly, or some kind of event listener filter option

content.body: The options bag for addEventListener doesn't seem like a great pattern to support specific options only for certain event types. But sure, I don't have strong feelings. This started off as a shower thought ;)

reviewed, thx for the ping

content.body: zcorpan: hah, so I just found a flaw, only submit buttons participate in form submission
content.formatted_body: zcorpan: hah, so I just found a flaw, only submit buttons participate in form submission

content.body: So maybe `dirname` needs to be more limited than `dir=auto` is after all
content.formatted_body: So maybe dirname needs to be more limited than dir=auto is after all

content.body: annevk: good catch. but it's "only" dead code, then, for `dirname`
content.formatted_body: annevk: good catch. but it's "only" dead code, then, for dirname

content.body: Ah I guess the form submission algorithm is still fine as the buttons are filtered early on, indeed
So it's just a matter of whether `dirname` applies and is conforming, which it should not be
content.formatted_body: So it's just a matter of whether dirname applies and is conforming, which it should not be

content.body: I'll change that
right
I was trying to implement this and the BaseButtonInputType class in WebKit was just like no, we don't handle form data here
i think that animations are supposed to "pause", so it probably makes sense that cancel doesnt fire
https://drafts.csswg.org/css-contain-2/#:~:text=While%20an%20element%20is%20skipped%2C%20CSS%20transitions%20and%20animations%20on%20the%20element%20do%20not%20update
i didnt implement any of the interactions between content-visibility and animations though, so i'm not the most knowledgable
I see your personal email is on the invite. Perhaps I shall add your work email, too?
I just removed and re-added you, hopefully that generated a useful notification.
It didn't. Not sure what's going on. It's not in Trash. I can find it using the Google Calendar web interface search, but then it can't open it. It's also not a declined invitation.
That's weird. Shall I add your work email to see if it helps you debug this further?
Could you add annevk@annevk.nl perhaps?
I don't think my Apple address will help, but I could be mistaken...
That address was already there, but I removed it, saved the event, and then added it again. Maybe you'll get a notification this time

Hiya, editor of CSS Variables here. Yes, $foo was an early proposed syntax. It started as `var-foo: blue; color: var(foo);`, then we discussed using $ and using the same name consistently in <https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-style/2012May/0744.html>, and then we explored a bunch of options that wouldn't require parsing changes (for a bit it was an underscore, then eventually the --, see <https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-style/2014Mar/0261.html>)
content.formatted_body: Hiya, editor of CSS Variables here. Yes, $foo was an early proposed syntax. It started as var-foo: blue; color: var(foo);, then we discussed using $ and using the same name consistently in https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-style/2012May/0744.html, and then we explored a bunch of options that wouldn't require parsing changes (for a bit it was an underscore, then eventually the --, see https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-style/2014Mar/0261.html)

content.body: The - was basically keeping it consistent with what we'd already done with vendor prefixes, and we just did that for all the custom things  https://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-style/2014Mar/0269.html
